Sawaddee ka welcome to hot Thai kitchen so today 
hot I kitchen is going to jump on the salted egg

train and if you've never been on this train or 
have no idea what training I'm talking about let

me tell you about it so in Asia in the past few 
years salted egg or salted egg yolk rather has

been like the flavor of the year for a few 
years now everything is getting salted egg

yolk flavors in it there's Lay's that's salted 
egg yolk flavor so everybody is using salted

egg yolk and nothing wrong with that salted 
egg yolk is really delicious so I thought I

would make a recipe that uses it so I'm gonna do 
salted egg yolk fried rice it's really easy it's

simple it's a great way to showcase the flavor 
of salted egg yolk so if you've never worked

with this ingredient before it's a good place to 
start and it's super delicious so in Thai this

dish is called Khao pad CAI kem sokha pod is fried 
rice cake hem is salted egg even though we're not

gonna use the white we're only gonna use the yolk 
it's not a dish that's like that exists like this

is sort of something that I've seen somewhere 
on the internet and I was like oh that's a good

idea so I sort of developed this recipe on my own 
all right let's get started so when we talk about

salted eggs or Chi Kim we're always talking about 
salted duck eggs not chicken eggs now you can buy

salted eggs whole raw or whole cooked which is 
good with congee or you can just buy the yolks

which is what we're gonna use say we're not using 
the whites no need to like dig the yolk out of a

whole egg the yolks are sold separately I get mine 
frozen and they come in a plastic bag like this

vacuum sealed yours might look a little different 
just wanted to show you what I used now with these

these are actually raw even though they're 
hard they are raw but they're heart because

they're cured in salt okay we're still going to 
cook them so what we're gonna do is we're gonna

just roughly chop these they're going to sort of 
disintegrate a bit when you cook them but I don't

want them to be completely disintegrated because 
I like little chunks of salted egg yolks in there

so the parts that dissolve we're gonna sort of 
coat the rice and make it richer and the parts

that remain chunky are going to be delicious 
and these how like the most interesting texture

it's like kind of firm and jello esque okay I 
wasn't counting but I think that's six yes I

have I had twelve now I have six yeah it's no 
big deal okay so that is our yolks apart from

that the ingredients are really really simple and 
I'm just gonna talk about them as we use them but

one more thing that I'm gonna use in this recipe 
that's important is Thai chilli paste so this is

number e cow or roasted Thai chili paste I've 
used this in many many recipes and if you can't

find it you can also make it at home it's not 
super difficult I have a recipe for that I'll

link to that below but it's made from lots of 
chilies shallots garlic cooked down together

and it's quite rich and sweet it really works 
well with the flavor of salted duck egg yolks

is it completely necessary no you can omit it 
it'll be a very different tasting dish in the

end but it'll still be fine I've done it before 
just substitute about a teaspoon of sugar because

this is quite a sweet paste so you want that 
extra sweetness they don't just leave it out

and not add anything okay all right let's get 
cooking so I've got some oil in the pan here

I'm gonna sear my protein first and for protein 
I am using shrimp which I love and fried rice

flavor goes really well with salted egg but you 
can use anything I've actually done it with tofu

as well and it worked out really great so 
whatever you want and as always I'm going

to sear my shrimp first so that I can control 
the dumbness of my shrimp as many as you want

okay we're just gonna quickly sear them on both 
sides and in this way your oil will have shrimp

flavor which will then flavor the rice it's 
all part of the plan so that's that takes like

literally one minute or maybe two depending on 
the size of your shrimp okay so I'm gonna remove

these these are fully cooked and we'll just top 
them you can toss them in at the end or you can

just save them and put it all on put them all 
on top with shrimp I tend to like to put them

on top at serving just because then you see all 
the shrimp right shrimp is expensive you want

people to know how many shrimp you're giving 
them and if you toss them into the rice and

you can't see okay in the same pan we're gonna 
now at the garlic and I haven't turned the heat

back on just because the pan was really hot and 
sometimes it's too hot and the garlic burns too

quickly so I like to add the garlic first and 
then turn the heat back on get that going you

might need a little bit more oil now once 
the garlic starts to brown just a little my

egg yolks my egg yolks go right here go in and 
what's gonna happen is the egg yolks will sort

of start to cook and crumble so when they're 
raw they will they're really jelly like as you

see and when they cook they become a little bit 
more sandy and then they will start to sort of

disintegrate a bit I'm just gonna deglaze my pan 
a little cuz I see some bits stuck there there we

go and just slowly cook the yolks until what you 
have is little chunks mix with dissolved parts

and it's gonna get foamy that's normal okay now 
I'm gonna add my vegetables that's kind of what

you're going for and and for vegetables I'm using 
what would have been long beans but I couldn't

find long bean so we're doing French green beans 
instead which is nice and skinny I like them and

some bell peppers can be glazed a little bit more 
there and then all our seasoning is going in I got

some fish sauce some soy sauce and our chili 
paste and get that all mixed in okay and then

now I'm gonna add just a little bit of sugar 
because there's quite a bit of salty stuff in

there it needs a little extra touch of sweetness 
and then I am going to add all my rice and now all

you need to do is work on distributing that rice 
with the sauce doesn't that look good oh my god

a lot of people think that you need to use old 
cold rice and you cook the day before for fried

rice you do not I literally just cook this rice 
the important thing is you don't use too much

water so I always put a little bit less water and 
then you spread it out let all the steam escape

and then you will have no problem with the rice 
clumping up or mushing rather now as an option

you can also add fresh unsalted egg in there 
too I like eggs and fried rice so that's what

I like to do add a little bit of egg there let 
it cook then I'm gonna put my rice over the egg

let it set a little bit and then toss I like 
the flavor of fresh egg in fried rice what it

also does is when you put an egg and fried rice 
it helps absorb greasy nuts and your fried rice

when made with an egg will not taste as greasy 
as fried rice that's made without egg and that's

it so easy I'm going to turn that off I'm going 
to toss in some fresh tomatoes because I feel

like this is such a rich recipe that the Pops of 
tomato really really helps keeps everything bright

beautiful but I also don't want to 
throw it in and then cook it cook it

cook it then the tomatoes become mushy and 
then finish it off with some green onions

because green onions make everything 
look better and that's it we're done

so to plate this we're gonna do this Asian 
style where we do the bowl method you know

what I'm talking about right so I never do that 
I don't think I've ever done that on the show but

we're gonna do it today so I'm gonna put some

looks good okay now we're gonna fill it with

but we will find out at the very least it will be

asian is that proof of authenticity right here 
now this is a very rich dish as I said I would

generally serve it with some sliced cucumber so

on the side I forgot the cucumber that's okay 
I'm gonna also add a wedge of lime Thai people

like to put lime on fried rice this is a very 
dull knife it's Adam it's not mine lime on the

side of fried rice precisely because fried rice 
can be quite rich and heavy and the lime helps

brighten and lighten it a little okay let's now

now if you notice you can see the little 
pieces of egg yolk still intact that's

what you're going for you don't want 
it completely dissolved because that

chewing on those chunks is the best part so a 
little bit of shrimp I'm gonna try it without

line first now I'm gonna just try it with

it's a really full-body fried rice I think it's 
how I'm gonna describe it if you haven't had

like super fine san dimas for lack of a better 
term but I mean that in a good way and if you've

had salted egg yolk you know what I'm talking 
about it's like it's creamy but it's also got

paste but no flavors are really like there's no

ask that layer of brightness and freshness that I

the vegetables oh it's just really good it's 
super good and it doesn't taste like we added

three yolks per serving and that might look like 
oh my god it's just gonna taste like I know it

doesn't like it it ends up being quite subtle so
